Award.AwardTitle: FRG: Collaborative Research: Chern classes in Iwasawa Theory
Award.AbstractNarration:
The Main Conjectures of Iwasawa theory which have been studied up to now relate the first Chern classes of Iwasawa modules and Selmer complexes to p-adic L-series. The object of this FRG project is to generalize this theory to higher Chern classes. One component of this generalization concerns how to define higher Chern classes in a way that facilitates studying them by L-series. This will be done by extending to the context of Iwasawa theory the adelic methods of Parshin and Beilinson. Another component of the generalization has to do with connecting higher Chern class invariants to L-series. To do this, one needs enough structure in the arithmetic problem to see into its higher codimension features using L-series. Three particular cases will be considered are (i) Greenberg's conjecture over totally real fields, (ii) Iwasawa theory for imaginary quadratic fields at split primes, and (iii) the function field case. Concerning (i), Greenberg has conjectured that the natural Iwasawa modules have trivial support in codimension one; the PIs will study their codimension two support using L-series. Concerning (ii), work of Rubin, and of Kings and Johnson-Leung, suggests that one should study second Chern classes via symbols in K_2 groups associated to pairs of p-adic L-series. Concerning (iii), the PIs will study the images under Chern class maps of classes defined by Witte in the function field case inside the higher relative K-groups of Iwasawa algebras. One further component of this project has to do with generalizing to higher Chern classes the reduction techniques used in proving first Chern class Main Conjectures. This involves generalizing to Iwasawa algebras the theory of tilting complexes and derived equivalences which is used in group representation theory and in studying Fourier-Mukai functors.

This proposal deals with fundamental questions about the groups of symmetries of algebraic equations. In the 1950's, Iwasawa began a new approach to the study of such equations by considering their behavior in infinite families. Iwasawa showed that many such families have well defined asymptotic behavior. This led to fundamental conjectures concerning the numerical growth rate of the symmetry groups arising from such families. The proof of such "Main Conjectures" has been one of the central goals of abstract algebra over the last 50 years. This proposal has to do with the refinements of these conjectures which deal with more precise measures of rates of growth. Concerning broad impacts, work on algebraic questions of this kind has led to the development of technology essential to society, such as the improved compression and secure transmission of data.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The research of this project falls in the area of number theory and arithmetic algebraic geometry. Number theory is the ancient study of properties of whole numbers with questions such as Fermat's problem: The equation x^n+y^n=z^n, for n bigger than two, has no solutions in integers (except the obvious ones, where one of x, y, z is zero). Algebraic geometry is the study of the properties of systems of polynomial equations in many variables and of their solution sets in real or complex numbers. (For example, x^n+y^n=z^n is such a polynomial equation. The set of points with coordinates (x, y, z), with x, y, z real solutions, is a conical surface in space.) In the terminology of this field, these solution sets are called "varieties''. Since the second half of the twentieth century, the two subjects of number theory and algebraic geometry have interacted in a profound way, with algebraic geometry providing tools for solving number theoretic problems.

Among many insights that facilitated this interaction was a construction of K. Iwasawa of Princeton. In the 1950's, Iwasawa realized that when one considers certain related arithmetic objects in a sequence their behaviour normalizes and can be studied with tools form algebraic geometry and analysis. For example, a sequence of such arithmetic objects is given by the solutions of the equations z^n=1 for n=2,3,4, ... in complex numbers, or those of the Fermat's equation x^n+y^n=z^n for n=2,3,4,... . Iwasawa then argued that the information given by certain numerical invariants obtained from this sequence in the limit can be captured by an analytic object which is the so-called zeta or L-function. In fact, he formulated a precise mathematical statement to that effect: this is the so-called "Iwasawa's main conjecture" that relates arithmetic and analysis in this precise sense. Iwasawa's ideas played a big role in a lot of recent progress in number theory. For example, there were instrumental in the celebrated solution of Fermat's Problem by A. Wiles in 1995.

 The project supported by this award has established a generalization of certain aspects of Iwasawa's study of the limiting behaviour of arithmetic invariants. We developed a framework in which some data can be captured in the case that the usual constructions of Iwasawa are supposed to produce no information. The technical term here is "capturing the higher codimension behavior of Iwasawa modules in the case that these are pseudo-null". We have also managed to show that in one particular situation in which the limiting object is obtained from a certain type of elliptic curve (a smooth curve given by an equation of the form y^2=x^3+ax+b with a and b rational numbers) this more refined invariant can be described using a pair of two L-functions. We have also investigated other related objects. In the course of our search for finding the correct analytic objects that would describe this refined version of Iwasawa's invariant we also looked for constructions inspired by mathematical physics. In particular, we studied an arithmetic version of some constructions related to the Cherns-Simons functional. The PI's research that was supported by this specific award has resulted in 6 publications, 5 of which in peer reviewed journals.

The project also involved organizing two international workshops on these topics. One in the Banff International Research Station (BIRS) in Banff, Canda, (June 2016) and one in Heidelberg Unversity, Germany (May 2018). These workshops were attended by many (about 40 each) participants several of which were graduate students and postdoctoral researchers. The project also involved the research of PhD graduate students working with the PI. The PI is currently supervising four graduate students. The PI presented research resulting from this project at several professional meetings and seminars, some of which were international.
